awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity to Develop Elementary STEM Teacher Leaders in New Jersey
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to serve the national need to develop highly qualified elementary STEM teacher leaders within high-need schools. The project will address the need to prepare elementary teachers to effectively teach in alignment with new climate change education standards adopted by the State of New Jersey. To address this need, the project will partner with teachers from local high-need elementary schools to gather information about their STEM knowledge related to climate change and their interests in future professional development workshops and graduate program opportunities in this area. Based on these interactions and gathered evidence, The College of New Jersey will modify its STEM education graduate courses and Environmental Sustainability Education certificate program to serve future elementary STEM teacher leaders. The project could contribute to developing elementary STEM teacher leaders in the region, preparing them to support implementation of the new climate change standards and to promote high-quality STEM education for students more generally.

This project at The College of New Jersey includes a partnership with the Hunterdon, Somerset, and Mercer County STEM Ecosystem (HSMC STEM Ecosystem), a partnership between schools, communities, businesses, and nonprofits dedicated to providing equitable access to STEM. The goal of the proposed project is to spend one year building capacity for a program to develop K-8 Master level teachers’ expertise in implementing STEM curriculum, with a specific focus on climate change. The project will build relationships with elementary STEM stakeholders from partner schools through introductory workshops and meetings exploring the new state K-12 climate change education standards. Additionally, the project will collect input from these stakeholders through surveys, site visits, and workshops. Evidence gathered will guide the revision of an existing 4-course graduate certificate program in Environmental Sustainability Education to address the new state standards for climate change content and to align with emerging elementary STEM teacher needs. Two leaders of a current Noyce Capacity Building effort in another state, also focused on elementary STEM teacher professional development, will serve as critical friends and mentors, providing feedback to the project. Additionally, an advisory board, which includes a STEM faculty member, an education faculty member, and a local elementary STEM teacher leader, will evaluate evidence gathered and progress towards project outcomes. The outcomes of this Noyce Capacity Building effort could produce a model for developing highly qualified elementary STEM teacher leaders generally, as well as elementary teacher leaders in climate change education more specifically. The involvement of stakeholders from local high-need elementary schools suggests that the resulting professional development and certificate program designs would effectively serve teachers in these contexts. The grounding of all efforts in the recently adopted New Jersey K-12 State climate education standards is likely to produce insights that could be a model for other campuses and teacher education programs across the state and beyond. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the effectiveness and retention of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Building Capacity to Develop Elementary STEM Teacher Leaders in New Jersey

The overarching objective for our capacity-building project was to work with teams of teachers and administrators from schools throughout our region to develop a clear vision and definition for STEM teacher leadership within our unique context, in order to craft a successful Track 3 Noyce Master Teacher Fellows (MTFs) proposal during the summer of 2023. Our goal was to ensure that this definition included STEM teaching and learning for all students, including those with learning disabilities and at the earliest grade levels. Further, in our state, which recently adopted climate change education standards across content areas K-12, it is essential that teacher leaders can integrate climate change education into their instructional practices, thus our definition needed to also integrate ideas around climate change education. 

At the beginning of this capacity-building year, we recruited stakeholder teams, composed of teachers and administrators from schools within our region. We successfully recruited a total of four teams. We met with these teams three times over the course of the capacity building year and throughout these meetings created a consensus model for what an inclusive and sustainable STEM teacher-leader was. 

We also solicited feedback from the stakeholder team group related to our plans for the future master teacher fellows project, during which MTFs would complete a 4-course graduate certificate in Environmental Sustainability Education during their first year.

Stakeholder teams provided feedback on the structure and content of our existing graduate certificate program in Environmental Sustainability Education. As a result, we restructured the program to allow for increased personalization and flexibility for the MTFs. 

During our NCE year, we disseminiated our work through conference presentations (at NSTA and the annual Noyce Conference) and built a partnership with the American Museum of Natural History to offer their Seminars on Science graduate courses as part of the elective choices in our graduate certificate program. 

The table below, describes Project Goals and Assessments as written in our initial proposal. We've added a column for outcomes. 

Project Goal

Assessment

Outcome

Identify potential partners at 5-7 high-needs elementary schools interested in partnering with us on a Track 3 grant.

This will be measured by the number of school-based teams participating in our stakeholder meetings. 

We developed clear and well-defined partnerships with stakeholder teams 4 high-needs elementary schools. Teams ranged in size from 2-5 members and all included an administrator and one or more teachers. These partners attended multiple meetings over the course of the 2022-23 academic year. 

Build relationships with a team from each interested school including teachers and administrators

This will be measured using survey responses post stakeholder meetings and attendance of other teachers from participating school at workshops 

Stakeholder team members provided survey responses after attending meetings throughout the duration of the project. They also provided written feedback on other project documents and verbal feedback throughout meetings, which allowed us to craft a clear vision and definition for inclusive and sustainable K-5 STEM teacher leadership.

Modify existing ESE graduate certificate with curriculum to best meet the needs of these teachers and schools to enhance K-8 STEM instruction AND effectively implement climate change across all content areas and grade levels

This will be measured by creating updated syllabi and course sequences for each of the four courses in the ESE graduate certificate.

The stakeholder teams provided verbal and written feedback to documents describing the key elements of the existing graduate certificate program including logistics (e.g. hybrid instructional format, courses offered in both the summer and academic year, etc) as well as the content (syllabi from all four key courses). They suggested one key modification to the program which was to include increased flexibility and personalization through allowing participants to take three of the four required courses and an elective OR all four courses as written. 

Electives included courses from within our existing offerings such as teacher research methods and advanced trends in education along with a suite of additional options offered through our new partnership with the American Museum of Natural History. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/04/2024
Modified by: Lauren Madden

Building Capacity to Develop Elementary STEM Teacher Leaders in New Jersey





The overarching objective for our capacity-building project was to work with teams of teachers and administrators from schools throughout our region to develop a clear vision and definition for STEM teacher leadership within our unique context, in order to craft a successful Track 3 Noyce Master Teacher Fellows (MTFs) proposal during the summer of 2023. Our goal was to ensure that this definition included STEM teaching and learning for all students, including those with learning disabilities and at the earliest grade levels. Further, in our state, which recently adopted climate change education standards across content areas K-12, it is essential that teacher leaders can integrate climate change education into their instructional practices, thus our definition needed to also integrate ideas around climate change education.


At the beginning of this capacity-building year, we recruited stakeholder teams, composed of teachers and administrators from schools within our region. We successfully recruited a total of four teams. We met with these teams three times over the course of the capacity building year and throughout these meetings created a consensus model for what an inclusive and sustainable STEM teacher-leader was.


We also solicited feedback from the stakeholder team group related to our plans for the future master teacher fellows project, during which MTFs would complete a 4-course graduate certificate in Environmental Sustainability Education during their first year.


Stakeholder teams provided feedback on the structure and content of our existing graduate certificate program in Environmental Sustainability Education. As a result, we restructured the program to allow for increased personalization and flexibility for the MTFs.


During our NCE year, we disseminiated our work through conference presentations (at NSTA and the annual Noyce Conference) and built a partnership with the American Museum of Natural History to offer their Seminars on Science graduate courses as part of the elective choices in our graduate certificate program.


The table below, describes Project Goals and Assessments as written in our initial proposal. We've added a column for outcomes.


 





Project Goal




Assessment




Outcome






Identify potential partners at 5-7 high-needs elementary schools interested in partnering with us on a Track 3 grant.




This will be measured by the number of school-based teams participating in our stakeholder meetings.




We developed clear and well-defined partnerships with stakeholder teams 4 high-needs elementary schools. Teams ranged in size from 2-5 members and all included an administrator and one or more teachers. These partners attended multiple meetings over the course of the 2022-23 academic year.






Build relationships with a team from each interested school including teachers and administrators




This will be measured using survey responses post stakeholder meetings and attendance of other teachers from participating school at workshops




Stakeholder team members provided survey responses after attending meetings throughout the duration of the project. They also provided written feedback on other project documents and verbal feedback throughout meetings, which allowed us to craft a clear vision and definition for inclusive and sustainable K-5 STEM teacher leadership.






Modify existing ESE graduate certificate with curriculum to best meet the needs of these teachers and schools to enhance K-8 STEM instruction AND effectively implement climate change across all content areas and grade levels




This will be measured by creating updated syllabi and course sequences for each of the four courses in the ESE graduate certificate.




The stakeholder teams provided verbal and written feedback to documents describing the key elements of the existing graduate certificate program including logistics (e.g. hybrid instructional format, courses offered in both the summer and academic year, etc) as well as the content (syllabi from all four key courses). They suggested one key modification to the program which was to include increased flexibility and personalization through allowing participants to take three of the four required courses and an elective OR all four courses as written.


Electives included courses from within our existing offerings such as teacher research methods and advanced trends in education along with a suite of additional options offered through our new partnership with the American Museum of Natural History.
